bug.short_desc: Some Android devices with fractional pixel ratio have strange rendering issues

long_desc.thetext:
At least on HTC One S devices, weird rendering flaws show up for mobile pages with an initial scale of 1.0 (as used by default in qx.Mobile). Those irregular rendering issues (typically staircased horizontal lines or broken fonts) are not tight to DOM elements. It seems to be caused by some buggy scaling of the device's graphics capabilities.
The device mentioned has a non-integer pixel ratio of 1.5 . A slight tweaking of the maximum and minimum scale triggers the rendering flaws to disappear: "width=device-width, initial-scale=1.0, user-scalable=yes, maximum-scale=1.01, minimum-scale=1.01"
Such a precautionary fix would should be provided by the framework.
* Added possibility to dynamically change the viewport attributes. * Added HTC Android fix

Removed any viewport content out of index.html of Mobile application or skeletons.
deed8d46a19bb0eafd6e6d6cd772a9b19d6a2500

Dynamic setting of viewport through JavaScript broke the viewport on Windows Phone 8.
The viewport on Windows Phone 8 was much too small, as the Windows Phone OS does not detect dynamic changes of the content attribute in the viewport meta tag.
That is why, we reverted the dynamic viewport setting.
The only reliable solution of setting the viewport content size is through the index.html .
The HTC One S might be solved by an Android OS update.
This is the meta tag which solves the bug on HTC One S:
<meta name="viewport" content="width=device-width, initial-scale=1.0, user-scalable=yes, minimum-scale=1.01, maximum-scale=1.01" />
Might be re-evaluated with next release. For the time being, a manual workaround is available as described above.
Other devices with a pixel ratio of 1.5 may also be affected. Another known device is Huawei Ascend Y300 on Android 4.1.1.
